title: Maqbool Fida Husain
summary: Maqbool Fida Husain (1915â€“2011) was a prominent Indian painter and film director, known for his narrative paintings in a modified Cubist style. A founding member of the Bombay Progressive Artists' Group, he significantly contributed to Indian modernism in the 1940s. His diverse themes included figures like Gandhi and Mother Teresa, as well as Indian epics and life. Husain's later works, featuring nude portrayals of Hindu deities, sparked considerable controversy, leading to lawsuits and his self-imposed exile from 2006 until his death. Despite controversies, his artistic legacy is immense, with a painting auctioned for a record $2.5 million in 2020. He also received a National Film Award and directed feature films.
key_points: Maqbool Fida Husain was an influential Indian painter and film director.
He was a founding member of the Bombay Progressive Artists' Group and a key figure in Indian modernism.
His distinct style involved narrative paintings executed in a modified Cubist manner, exploring diverse themes from Indian culture and history.
His works, particularly nude portrayals of Hindu deities, generated significant controversy, leading to legal challenges and his self-imposed exile.
He was honored with the National Film Award for Best Experimental Film for 'Through the Eyes of a Painter' in 1967.
Husain's painting 'Voices' was auctioned for a record $2.5 million in 2020, highlighting the enduring value of his art.
timeline: 1940s: Associated with Indian modernism and co-founded the Bombay Progressive Artists' Group.
1967: Received the National Film Award for Best Experimental Film for 'Through the Eyes of a Painter'.
2004: Directed the film 'Meenaxi: A Tale of Three Cities', screened at Cannes.
2006: Began a self-imposed exile due to controversies.
2020: His painting 'Voices' auctioned for a record $2.5 million.
important_figures: Owais Husain (artist son, collaborated on film)
current_status: Maqbool Fida Husain passed away in 2011, but his legacy as a pivotal figure in Indian modern art continues to be significant. His works remain highly sought after in the art market, as evidenced by recent record-breaking auction prices. Discussions surrounding artistic freedom versus religious sentiment, sparked by his controversial works, persist in India.
future_prospects: Future prospects include continued academic study and critical analysis of his extensive body of work, solidifying his place in global art history. There is potential for further exhibitions and retrospectives of his art, both in India and internationally. His influence is expected to continue shaping the discourse on modern Indian art and the boundaries of artistic expression.
